titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Martin Shubik Papers, 1938-2017 and undated RL.01181
titlestmt.author: Processed by: Spencer Banzhaf, Debbera Carson, Jonathan Cogliano, Danilo Da Costa, Joanne Fairhurst, Catherine Hersfeld, Paula Jeannet Mangiafico, Trey McLean, Laurin Penland and Matthew Warren; machine-readable finding aid created by: Danilo Da Costa, Joanne Fairhurst, Catherine Hersfeld, Paula Jeannet Mangiafico, Don Sechler, and Matthew Warren

publicationstmt.publisher: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

resorted existing description into clearer series; added accessions 2018-0045, 2018-0058.

repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.abstract: Martin Shubik is Professor Emeritus of Economics and Seymour H. Knox Professor of Mathematical Institutional Economics at Yale University and the Cowles Foundation for Research in Economics. The Martin Shubik Papers span the years 1938 through 2017, and consist of his correspondence, research, writings, and his collaborations and professional affiliations.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Martin Shubik Papers, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The papers of Martin Shubik were received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a gift and as deposits between 1992 and 2021.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by RL staff. Updated by Jon Cogliano in June 2018.

Recognized by the American Economic Association as a Distinguished Fellow for his contributions to the field

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: The Martin Shubik Papers document his career as an economist. This collection provides an overview of his professional activities, particularly his research and writings on general equilibrium, game theory, the core, oligopoly and market structure, defense and war game analysis, nuclear deterrence, behavior and risk, financial institutions, and money.

The collection also documents his collaborations and communications with prominent economists, including Kenneth Arrow, Gerard Debreu, Milton Friedman, Oskar Morgenstern, John Nash, Paul Samuelson, Herbert Scarf, Lloyd Shapley, and others.

Along with his own scholarship and writings, the collection documents Shubik's time at IBM, his consultancy work for the RAND Corporation, expert witness testimony, his role as a conference organizer and participant, and other professional activities; and his departmental roles, committee work, and teaching contributions at Yale University.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged into the following series: Organized into the following series: Audiovisual Materials, Correspondence, Professional Service, Research and Notes, Writings, Academia, and Personal.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Access restricted; accession 2019-0160 is unprocessed and requires additional arrangement, description, and/or screening. Contact research services for more information.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains fifteen audio tapes on reels varying in size from 8" to 3", chiefly lectures given by Shubik. Drafts of many of these lectures may be found in the Writings and Research Series. Titles are taken from original labels and notes on containers. Arranged alphabetically by title.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Original audiovisual materials are closed to use. Use of these materials may require production of listening or viewing copies. Please contact Research Services before coming to use this collection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains Shubik's correspondence organized by date and alphabetically by last name, preserving Shubik's original organization. Among his most frequent correspondents is his longtime collaborator Lloyd Shapley, as well as other prominent economists, including Kenneth Arrow, Gerard Debreu, Milton Friedman, Oskar Morgenstern, John Nash, Paul Samuelson, and Herbert Scarf, among others. The series also contains Shubik's non-academic correspondence with newspapers, magazines, companies, and museums.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains Shubik's arranged correspondence, arranged chronologically by year. Correspondence ranges from his early career at IBM to his time at Yale University. Correspondents of note include Kenneth Arrow, Gerard Debreu, Oskar Morgenstern, John Nash, Herbert Scarf, and Lloyd Shapley, among others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains Shubik's alphabetically arranged correspondence. Correspondents of note include: Kenneth Arrow, Gerard Debreu, Ralph Gomory, John Nash, and Eric Smith. This subseries also contains Shubik's correspondence with publishers and academic journals.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series documents Shubik's professional activities. These include: conference and workshop presentations; conferences and workshops organized by Shubik; files related to service with professional organizations; consulting for various companies and organizations; and expert witness testimony.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains alphabetically arranged files related to Shubik's participation in and organization of various conferences and workshops, as well as his involvement in professional organizations. Also included are grant proposals, and files for his work to establish a Museum of Money.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes Shubik's notes and correspondence for research projects, notes from classes taken as a student, and portion of his collection of academic writings by others. Research notes include files projects on game theory, simulation, and auctions, among other topics.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes files for classes taken by Shubik at the University of Toronto and Princeton University arranged alphabetically. Of note are files for classes taught by Oskar Morgenstern and Jacob Viner.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains files for Shubik's various research projects, arranged alphabetically, including work on game theory, simulation, auctions, and bargaining. This subseries also includes Shubik's research reports from his time at IBM.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes select articles, book chapters, and books used in Shubik's research arranged alphabetically. Includes works in English, French, German, Chinese, and Russian. Chinese and Russian titles are at the end of the list.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains copies, reprints, drafts, notes, and other documents associated with Shubik's published works. These include: reprints and copies of published journal articles and book chapters; books; and documents from his referee activity for academic journals and publishers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes published papers assigned an index number from an enumerated list in Shubik's CV and arranged by index number.
